title: Brittany Snow opens up about backlash from sharing mental health struggles 'too early'
text:
CLOSE Brittany Snow, DeWanda Wise and Gina Rodriguez say they all found "Someone Great" among their own co-stars on the Netflix romantic comedy. (May 17) AP

Brittany Snow says she doesn't regret opening up about her mental health "too early" during a time when honesty about personal struggles was ridiculed, not celebrated.

The "Almost Family" actress, 33, revealed her nine-year battle with anorexia, depression and self-harm in 2007. Much to Snow's surprise, her experience was slammed as a mere publicity stunt.

"I think there was still a stigma around sharing so much truth, and it kind of got seen as me being self-indulgent or trying to gain attention," she told InStyle. "I definitely wasn't ready for that. I was too young and not prepared for what was going to happen."

Speaking about mental health was a taboo over a decade ago, but times have certainly changed. Celebrities are now hailed for being candid about their trials and tribulations, including Selena Gomez and Justin Beiber, who both shared their personal struggles.

Snow, however, didn't receive that kind of support from the world in 2007.

In fact, she called the response downright "awful." The backlash forced her to step out of the limelight following an onset of crippling anxiety: "I needed to, for health reasons."

Brittany Snow arrives at the 71st Emmy Awards at the Microsoft Theater. (Photo: Dan MacMedan, Dan MacMedan-USA TODAY via Imagn)

Looking back, the "Hairspray" alum said the backlash "wasn't even that bad," she just didn't "have the tools to really be able to help people and help myself."

The experience lead Snow to create the Love is Louder movement, a bully-free online community built to spread postivity to anyone facing similar situations.

"Now, so many people are so open with their stories, and it's very, very cool and accepted that people are sharing their truth," Snow said. "I might've spoken too early, but at the same time, it started and was the impetus for so many changes in my life that have worked out really well, so it's okay."

Snow credits her healing to hypnotherapy and her strong support system. Despite the initial critiscm, Snow said she's proud to have helped paved the way for others to open up about their internal battles without the fear of being shunned.

“I think that that's a really nice thing to feel like I was a part of, where I can tell my daughter one day, ‘I was really honest when a lot of people weren't being honest,’” she says. “In my thirties, I can confidently say that it's almost like another life that I look back and [say], ‘Wow, I was so anxious and scared, and now I'm just not.'"
